revision.comment: Reverting possible vandalism by [[Special:Contribs/2600:1700:9460:5A40:15FF:72F2:FB5D:F0FF|2600:1700:9460:5A40:15FF:72F2:FB5D:F0FF]] to version by Moe1810. [[WP:CBFP|Report False Positive?]] Thanks, [[WP:CBNG|ClueBot NG]]. (3453243) (Bot)
revision.text:
{{other people}} {{BLP sources|date=May 2018}} {{infobox person | name = Henry Winkler | image = Henry Winkler (8530353007).jpg | alt = Winkler speaking at the Foreign Office in London, England on 5 March 2013 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=y|1945|10|30}} | birth_place = [[Manhattan, New York]], U.S. | education = [[Emerson College]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[Yale University]] {{small|([[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]])}} | occupation = Actor, director, comedian, producer, author | years_active = 1967–present | spouse = {{marriage|Stacey Weitzman
|May 5, 1978}} | children = 3, including [[Max Winkler (director)|Max]] | relatives = [[Richard Belzer]] (cousin) }} '''Henry Franklin Winkler''', [[ OBE]] (born October 30, 1945) is an American actor, comedian, director, producer, and author.{{cite news|last1=Drabble|first1=Emily|title=Henry Winkler: I didn't read a book myself until I was 31 years old|url=https://www.theguardian.com/childrens-books-site/2014/may/26/henry-winkler-the-fonz-interview-hank-zipzer-dyslexia|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=26 May 2014}} He played the role of [[Greaser (subculture)|greaser]] [[Fonzie|Arthur "Fonzie" Fonzarelli]], the [[breakout character]] of the 1970s American sitcom ''[[Happy Days]]''.{{cite news|last1=Wilson|first1=John M.|title=Can Henry Winkler Outgrow 'The Fonz'?|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E05EFDA143FE23BA15750C2A9639C946790D6CF|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=23 May 1976|page=372}} He also starred as Sy Mittleman on [[Adult Swim]]'s ''[[Childrens Hospital (TV Series)|Childrens Hospital]]'',{{cite news|last1=Spiegel|first1=Danny|title=Henry Winkler Checks in to Adult Swim's Childrens Hospital|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/henry-winkler-checks-1022080/|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[TV Guide]]|date=20 August 2010}} and as Eddie R. Lawson on [[USA Networks]]'s ''[[Royal Pains]]''. Winkler also had notable guest-starring roles on ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'' as [[Barry Zuckerkorn]] and [[List of Parks and Recreation characters|Dr. Saperstein]] on ''[[Parks and Recreation]]''.{{cite news|last1=Lewis|first1=Andy|title=Henry Winkler Spills 'Royal Pains' Secrets, Reveals the Only Way He'd Do 'Dancing With the Stars' (Q&A)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/henry-winkler-spills-royal-pains-207891|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=3 July 2011}} In 2018, he began appearing as Gene Cousineau on the [[HBO]] comedy ''[[Barry (TV series)|Barry]]''. For his role on ''Happy Days'', Winkler won two [[Golden Globe Awards]] and earned three [[Primetime Emmy Award|Emmy Award]] nominations for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]]. He was also nominated for an [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series|Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series]] for his role on ''[[The Practice]]''. == Early life == Henry Franklin Winkler was born on October 30, 1945, on the [[West Side (Manhattan)|West Side]] of [[Manhattan, New York]],{{cite news|last1=Herman|first1=Karen|title=Emmy TV Legends: Henry Winkler|url=http://www.emmytvlegends.org/interviews/people/henry-winkler|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[Archive of American Television]]|publisher=[[Emmys]]|date=10 November 2006}}{{cite web|title=Henry Franklin Winkler - United States Public Records|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QJXJ-Y7QK|website=[[FamilySearch]]|accessdate=20 April 2015}} the son of homemaker Ilse Anna Marie (''née'' Hadra; 1913–2002) and lumber import-export{{cite web|url=https://people.com/archive/happy-daze-vol-55-no-18/|title=Happy Daze|author=|date=|website=people.com|accessdate=1 August 2018}} company president Harry Irving Winkler (1903–1995). His parents were German Jews who emigrated from [[Berlin]] to the U.S. in 1939, on the eve of [[World War II]]. Winkler said that his parents came to the U.S. for a six-month business trip but knew they were never going back. His father smuggled the only assets the family had left (family jewels disguised as a box of chocolates) that he carried under his arm. Although they did not keep [[kosher]], Winkler was raised in the traditions of [[Conservative Judaism]],{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/welcome-to-my-world-henry-winkler-1-1352707 |title=Welcome to my world: Henry Winkler |work=[[The Scotsman]] |date=15 May 2009 |accessdate=9 December 2014}}{{cite web|last=Nathan|first=John|url=http://www.thejc.com/arts/arts-features/114603/happy-days-after-hard-knocks |title=Happy days after hard knocks |work= [[The Jewish Chronicle]] |date=9 January 2014 |accessdate=9 December 2014}} but said that he was not religious as an adult. The family attended [[Congregation Habonim]], where his mother ran the [[Judaica]] shop. His parents were founding members of the temple. Winkler has a sister named Beatrice.{{cite web|last1=Maron|first1=Marc|title=Episode 593 - Henry Winkler|url=http://www.wtfpod.com/podcast/episodes/episode_593_-_henry_winkler|website=[[WTF with Marc Maron]]|accessdate=18 April 2015|publisher=Audio podcast interview|date=13 April 2015}} Winkler has said that he was very anxious as a child because of his undiagnosed [[dyslexia]] and that he was considered to be "slow, stupid, not living up to my potential." As his father spoke 11 languages and could do math in his head, he did not understand Winkler's problems at school and why Winkler would celebrate a C grade. He also said that his relationship with his parents was strained, due at least partially to their attitude towards his undiagnosed dyslexia.{{cite web|url=http://dyslexia.yale.edu/Winkler.html |title=Henry Winkler, Actor, Producer, Author |work=The Yale Center for Dyslexia & Creativity |accessdate=15 December 2012}} His father referred to him as "dumb dog" and often punished him for his difficulties in school. Winkler attended P.S. 87 on W. 78th Street which remains in operation today, and then graduated from [[McBurney School]] in 1963 which was located in Manhattan's [[Upper West Side]] neighborhood. Winkler said he did not graduate with his class because of his learning disability and problems with a geometry class, which he finally passed after attending summer school. In 1967, Winkler received his [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] from [[Emerson College]]. At Emerson, he was a member of the Alpha Pi Theta Fraternity. In 1970, Winkler earned an [[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]] from the [[Yale School of Drama]]. In 1972 Winkler returned to New York City, auditioned for, and was cast in ''42 Seconds from Broadway''.{{cite web|url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-cast-staff/henry-winkler-74273|title=Henry Winkler – Broadway Cast & Staff|first=|last=The Broadway League|date=|website=ibdb.com|accessdate=1 August 2018}} In 1978, Emerson awarded Winkler an honorary [[Doctor of Humane Letters|DHL]]. He has also received an honorary DHL from [[Austin College]].
"During his high school and college years, he studied in Lausanne, Switzerland and worked in a lumber mill in a small German town."{{cite web|url=http://www.walker.co.uk/contributors/Henry-Winkler-8201.aspx|title=Walker Books - Henry Winkler|author=|date=|website=walker.co.uk|accessdate=1 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.hallmarkchannel.com/the-most-wonderful-time-of-the-year/cast/henry-winkler|title=Henry Winkler as Uncle Ralph on The Most Wonderful Time of the Year|author=|date=|website=Hallmark Channel|accessdate=1 August 2018}}
== Career == === Acting === Winkler said he had wanted to be an actor from the time he was a young child. Winkler's first job on television was as an extra on a game show in New York. He received $10 for the role. After working in theater and getting loved from a play in Washington, Winkler returned to New York City and supported himself by appearing in television commercials, one year doing more than 30. He was able to support himself with the commercial work so he could do theater for free at [[Manhattan Theater Club]]. He also appeared in 1973 in season four of ''[[The Mary Tyler Moore Show]]'' in the episode "The Dinner Party" as Rhoda's date, Steve Waldman, and in episodes of ''[[The Bob Newhart Show]]'' and ''[[Rhoda]]''. ==== ''Happy Days'' ==== [[File:Happy days motorcycle richie fonzie 1977.JPG|right|thumb|225px|Richie ([[Ron Howard]]) takes a turn on Fonzie's motorcycle]] Although Winkler had already shot the film ''[[The Lords of Flatbush]],'' he was relatively unknown. In 1973, a year before that film was released, producer Tom Miller was instrumental in Winkler getting cast for the role of Arthur Herbert Fonzarelli, nicknamed "The Fonz" or "[[Fonzie]]", in ''[[Happy Days]]'', which first aired in January 1974.{{cite news|last1=Armstrong|first1=Lois|title=It's The Fonz! Ayyyy—the Fonz Is a Smash, but Henry Winkler Finds Some Nightmares in His Happy Daze|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20066500,00.html|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=24 May 1976}} For ''Happy Days'', director/producer [[Garry Marshall]] originally had in mind a completely opposite physical presence. Marshall sought to cast a hunky, blonde, Italian model-type male in the role of Fonzie, intended as a stupid [[Foil (literature)|foil]] to the real star, [[Ron Howard]]. However, when Winkler interpreted the role in auditions, Marshall immediately snapped him up. According to Winkler, "The Fonz was everybody I wasn't. He was everybody I wanted to be."[http://www2.oprah.com/tows/slide/200802/20080226/slide_20080226_350_107.jhtml Remarks to Oprah Winfrey] on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]],'' original airdate February 26, 2008 Winkler's character, though remaining very much a rough-hewn outsider, gradually became the focus of the show as time passed (in particular after the departure of Ron Howard).{{cite news|title=Happy Days - The Third Season|work= [[DVD Talk]]|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/31528/happy-days-the-third-season|accessdate=16 August 2010|date=27 November 2007}} Initially, ABC executives did not want to see the Fonz wearing leather, thinking the character would appear to be a criminal. The first 13 episodes show Winkler wearing two different kinds of [[windbreaker]] jackets, one of which was green. As Winkler said in a [[TV Land]] interview, "It's hard to look cool in a green windbreaker". Marshall argued with the executives about the jacket. In the end, a compromise was made. Winkler could only wear the leather jacket in scenes with his motorcycle, and from that point on, the Fonz was never without his motorcycle until season 2. ''Happy Days'' ended its run in 1984. ==== 1960s & 1970s ==== From 1968 to 1972, Winkler appeared in 14 Yale Repertory Theater productions, including Shakespeare's "Coriolanus" (May 1968) & "Macbeth" (February 1971), Gogol's "The Government Inspector" (February 1970), the World Premiere of "Gimpel the Fool" (an Isaac Bashevis Singer adaptation, October 1970) and "TWO BY BRECHT AND WEILL: The Little Mahagonny and The Seven Sins" (May–June 1971 & January 1972)."www.library.yale.edu/humanities/theater/YRT_season_history_1966-1979.doc" During his decade on ''Happy Days'', Winkler also starred in a number of movies, including ''[[The Lords of Flatbush]]'' (1974), playing a troubled [[Vietnam-American War|Vietnam veteran]] in ''[[Heroes (1977 film)|Heroes]]'' (1977), ''[[The One and Only (1978 film)|The One and Only]]'' (1978), and ''[[An American Christmas Carol]]'' (TV movie, 1979). That year Winkler was also narrator and executive producer of ''[[Who Are the DeBolts? And Where Did They Get Nineteen Kids?]]'', a [[documentary film]] about Dorothy and Bob DeBolt, an American couple who have [[adoption|adopted]] 14 children, some of whom are severely disabled war orphans (in addition to raising Dorothy's five biological children and Bob's biological daughter). The film won an [[Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature|Academy Award for Best Feature-length Documentary]] in 1978,{{cite web |url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/54399/Who-Are-the-DeBolts-And-Where-Did-They-Get-19-Kids-/details |title=NY Times: Who Are the DeBolts? And Where Did They Get Nineteen Kids? |accessdate=2008-11-15|work=NY Times}} as well as the [[Directors Guild of America Awards 1978|Directors Guild of America Award]] and the Humanitas Award for producer and director [[John Korty]] in 1979. A 50-minute version of the film shown on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] in December 1978, earned a 1979 [[Emmy Award]] for Outstanding Individual Achievement - Informational Program and an Emmy nomination for Outstanding Informational Program for Winkler, Korty, and producers Warren Lockhart and Dan McCann. Winkler was also one of the hosts of the 1979 [[Music for UNICEF Concert]]. ==== 1980s ==== After ''Happy Days'' ended, Winkler concentrated on producing and directing. Within months of the program's cancellation, he and [[John Rich (director)|John Rich]] had collaborated to establish '''Winkler-Rich Productions;''' whenever Rich or Ann Daniels was uninvolved, his company was called '''Fair Dinkum Productions.''' He chose the name in a nod to Australia, where "[[Australian English vocabulary|fair dinkum]]" is a common Australian term suggesting a person or thing is "direct," "honest," "fair," or "authentic". He produced several television shows, including ''[[MacGyver (1985 TV series)|MacGyver]],'' ''[[So Weird]],'' and ''[[Mr. Sunshine (1986 TV series)|Mr. Sunshine]],'' with Rich; ''[[Sightings (TV series)|Sightings]],'' in which Daniels was involved; the 1985 made-for-television film ''[[Scandal Sheet (1985 film)|Scandal Sheet]],'' for which he was [[executive producer]]; and the game shows ''Wintuition'' and ''[[Hollywood Squares]]'' (the latter from 2002–2004, occasionally serving as a sub-announcer). Winkler appeared in ''[[Night Shift (film)|Night Shift]]'', a 1982 American comedy film directed by [[Ron Howard]]. He also directed several movies including the [[Billy Crystal]] movie ''[[Memories of Me]]'' (1988) and ''[[Cop and a Half]]'' (1993) with [[Burt Reynolds]]. {{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} [[File:Henry Winkler at the AIDS Project Los Angeles (APLA) benefit cropped.jpg|thumb|left|187px|September 1990]] ==== 1990s ==== As the 1990s began, Winkler returned to acting. In 1991, he starred in the controversial made-for-television film ''[[Absolute Strangers]],'' as a husband forced to make a decision regarding his comatose wife and his unborn baby. In 1994, he returned to TV with the short-lived comedy series ''[[Monty (TV series)|Monty]]'' on [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]] and co-starred with [[Katharine Hepburn]] in the holiday TV movie ''[[One Christmas (film)|One Christmas]]''.{{cite news|last1=Lenox|first1=Mariana|title=One Christmas|url=http://reelandunscripted.com/one-christmas-1994/|accessdate=26 August 2015|work=Reel and Unscripted}} In 1996, his scene-stealing, uncredited role in ''[[Scream (1996 film)|Scream]]'' (as foul-mouthed high school principal [[List of Scream characters#Principal Himbry|Arthur Himbry]]) thrust his onscreen career back into the mainstream. Shortly afterwards, [[Adam Sandler]] asked Winkler to appear in ''[[The Waterboy]]'' (1998). In 1999, he became an executive producer for the Disney Channel original series ''[[So Weird]]''. He would later make a special guest appearance in the second season's Halloween episode titled "Boo". ==== 2000s ==== ''[[The Waterboy]]'' sparked a fast friendship, and ongoing professional relationship, between Sandler and Winkler. Winkler would go on to appear in at least three other Sandler films: ''[[Little Nicky]]'' (2000, where he plays himself, covered in bees), ''[[Click (2006 film)|Click]]'' (2006, as the protagonist's father), and ''[[You Don't Mess with the Zohan]]'' (2008, again playing himself). He also had small roles in movies such as ''[[Down to You]]'' (2000), ''[[Holes (film)|Holes]]'' (2003), and ''[[I Could Never Be Your Woman]]'' (2007). He is known as a regular collaboeateur with Adam Sandler in his movies. Winkler had a recurring role as incompetent lawyer [[Barry Zuckerkorn]] in the [[Fox Television]] comedy ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]].'' In one episode, his character hopped over a dead shark lying on a pier,{{cite episode |title=Motherboy XXX |series=Arrested Development |season=2 |number=13 |network=Fox |date=2005-03-15 |time=11:30}} a reference to his role in the origin of the phrase, from a two-part episode of ''Happy Days,'' "[[jumping the shark]]." After that episode, Winkler, in interviews, stated that he was the only person to have "jumped the shark" twice.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} When Winkler moved to [[CBS]] for one season to star in 2005–06's ''[[Out of Practice]],'' his role as the Bluth family lawyer on ''Arrested Development'' was taken over by ''Happy Days'' co-star [[Scott Baio]] in the fall of 2005, shortly before the acclaimed but [[Nielsen ratings|Nielsen]]-challenged show ceased production. Winkler has guest-starred on television series such as ''[[Numbers (TV series)|Numb3rs]]'', ''[[The Bob Newhart Show]]'' (as Miles Lascoe, a parolee just out of jail—he was in jail for armed robbery, twice), ''[[South Park]]'', ''[[The Practice]]'', ''[[The Drew Carey Show]]'', ''[[The Simpsons]]'' (playing a member of a biker gang—in one scene, he calls Marge "Mrs. S", a reference to Fonzie calling ''Happy Days'' matriarch Marion Cunningham "Mrs. C"), ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'', ''[[Third Watch]]'', ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]]'', ''[[Crossing Jordan]]'', ''[[Family Guy]]'', ''[[King of the Hill]],'' and ''[[Kick Buttowski: Suburban Daredevil]]''. The [[Weezer]] video for 1994's "[[Buddy Holly (song)|Buddy Holly]]" edited period footage of Henry Winkler as the Fonz, as well as a double shot from behind to create the illusion that Fonzie and other characters were watching Weezer as they performed in Arnold's restaurant. He appeared on [[KTTV]]'s ''[[Good Day L.A.]]'' and in one appearance, while substituting for [[Steve Edwards (talk show host)|Steve Edwards]], Winkler reunited with fellow ''Happy Days'' cast member [[Marion Ross]]. Winkler made a cameo appearance in the band [[Say Anything (band)|Say Anything]]'s video for "[[Wow, I Can Get Sexual Too]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1054077/say-anything-gets-sexy-with-fonzie-begins-new-cd |title=Say Anything Gets Sexy With Fonzie, Begins New CD |publisher=Billboard |date=2007-03-09 |accessdate=2014-12-09}}{{YouTube|zaOxwINr5GA}} A close friend of actor [[John Ritter]], the two led a Broadway ensemble cast in [[Neil Simon]]'s ''[[The Dinner Party (play)|The Dinner Party]]'' in 2000. Winkler was reunited as a guest star on Ritter's sitcom ''[[8 Simple Rules|8 Simple Rules (for Dating my Teenage Daughter)]]'' in 2003 by Ritter's request. On September 11, Ritter became ill during filming, and unexpectedly died. A stunned, grief-stricken Winkler was interviewed by [[Mary Hart (TV personality)|Mary Hart]] of ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' and various other entertainment news sources. [[File:HenryWinklerAug08.jpg|thumb|right|187px|at the 2008 [[Fan Expo Canada]]]] In 2008, he appeared in two Christmas movies, in the Hallmark Channel movie ''[[The Most Wonderful Time of the Year (film)|The Most Wonderful Time of the Year]]'' as a retired cop who plays matchmaker between his niece and a drifter he befriends, and in ''[[Merry Christmas, Drake & Josh]]'' as the judge who orders Drake and Josh to give a young girl "the best Christmas ever" or be sent to jail. In 2009, Winkler provided the voice of Willard Deutschebog, a suicidal German teacher, in the Fox comedy series, ''[[Sit Down, Shut Up (U.S. TV series)|Sit Down, Shut Up]].''{{cite web|url=http://sitdownshutupwiki.fox.com/?t=anon|title=Sit Down, Shut Up|publisher=Fox|accessdate=2009-04-14}} ==== 2010s ==== In the summer/fall 2010 season, Winkler joined the cast of [[Adult Swim]]'s television adaptation of [[Rob Corddry]]'s web series ''[[Childrens Hospital (TV Series)|Childrens Hospital]],'' playing a stereotypically feckless hospital administrator. In late September 2010, Winkler provided the voice of Professor Nathaniel Zib in the ''[[Hero Factory (TV series)|Lego Hero Factory]]'' mini-series, ''Rise of the Rookies.'' In 2011, Winkler guest starred as [[Ambush Bug]] in the series finale of ''[[Batman: The Brave and the Bold]].'' In August 2012, Winkler announced on Twitter that he would be returning to the fourth season of ''[[Arrested Development (TV series)|Arrested Development]].''{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/hwinkler4real/status/241542660526063616 |title=Twitter / hwinkler4real: I AM SUPPOSED TO BE MEMORIZING |publisher=Twitter.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-15}} Winkler appeared in the film ''[[Here Comes the Boom]],'' released October 12, 2012, as the music teacher at Wilkinson High School. Between 2013 and 2015, Winkler appeared in 9 episodes of ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' as Dr. Saperstein, father of Jean-Ralphio and Mona-Lisa. He starred in the British television adaption of his ''[[Hank Zipzer (TV series)|Hank Zipzer]]'' book series as the teacher, Mr. Rock. Mr. Rock was based on a music teacher Winkler had in high school at [[McBurney School|McBurney]]. Winkler said that the real Mr. Rock believed in him and was the only teacher there who he felt did. The show aired on the [[CBBC Channel]] in the [[United Kingdom]].{{cite web|last1=Blevis|first1=Mark|title=Interview with Henry Winkler|url=http://justonemorebook.com/2008/01/21/interview-with-henry-winkler/|website=Just One More Book!!|accessdate=20 April 2015|date=21 January 2008}} In March 2010, Winkler was cast in a recurring role on USA Network's ''[[Royal Pains]]'', as Hank and Evan's ne'er-do-well father Eddy. Winkler is a spokesman for reverse mortgages through [[Quicken Loans]]. [[File:Stolperstein Nikolsburger Platz 1 (Wilmd) Helmut Theodor Winkler.jpg|thumb|upright=1| "[[Stolperstein]]" (stumbling block),
Helmut Theodor Winkler,
Nikolsburger Platz 1,
[[Berlin-Wilmersdorf]], Germany]] Beginning in the summer of 2016, Winkler has starred in, and executive produced the NBC series ''[[Better Late Than Never (TV series)|Better Late Than Never]]'', which co-stars other entertainment legends (boxer George Foreman, actor William Shatner, football player and commentator [[Terry Bradshaw]]) and Jeff Dye. In 2016, they traveled to Asia; in 2017, they visited Europe, partaking in various European traditions. They discovered Winkler's family roots in Berlin, Germany, at a brass plaque, in the pavement in front of the house of Helmut Winkler, an uncle, who died in [[Auschwitz concentration camp|Auschwitz]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jimdobson/2017/12/07/exclusive-interview-with-william-shatner-and-henry-winkler-on-their-outrageous-new-travel-series/|title=Exclusive Interview With William Shatner And Henry Winkler On Their Outrageous New Travel Series|first=Jim|last=Dobson|date=|website=forbes.com|accessdate=1 August 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.tracesofwar.com/sights/32602/Stumbling-Stones-Nikolsburger-Platz-1.htm|title=Stumbling Stones: Nikolsburger Platz 1 - Berlin-Wilmersdorf|author=|date=|website=Traces Of War|accessdate=1 August 2018}}
"So, the story was that my father was able to get a six-week work visa to come to New York City, but Uncle Helmut{{cite web|url=https://www.geni.com/people/Helmut-Winkler/6000000073648982001|title=Helmut Theodor Winkler|author=|date=|website=geni family tree|accessdate=1 August 2018}} was having a white dinner jacket made and it was going to be ready the next day. So, instead of going with my dad and my mom and leaving Berlin, he stayed an extra day, and that night was taken by the Nazis."
- Henry Winkler, [[Better Late Than Never (TV series)|Better Late Than Never]] season 2, episode 4{{cite web|url=https://www.springfieldspringfield.co.uk/view_episode_scripts.php?tv-show=better-late-than-never-2016&episode=s02e04|title=Better Late Than Never (2016) s02e04 Episode Script|author=|date=|website=episode scripts|accessdate=1 August 2018}}
Beginning in 2018, Winkler has appeared in the role of acting coach Gene Cousineau in the [[Bill Hader]]-helmed [[HBO]] comedy ''[[Barry (TV series)|Barry]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/henry-winkler-hbo-apos-apos-110002647.html|title=Henry Winkler on HBO's 'Barry' and the Poetry of Good Cursing|author=|date=|website=yahoo.com|accessdate=1 August 2018}} === Theater === Winkler's audition for the [[Yale School of Drama]] was to be a [[Shakespeare]] monologue, which he promptly forgot, so he made up his own Shakespeare monologue. Out of a class of 25 actors, 11 finished. During summers, he and his classmates opened a summer stock theater called New Haven Free Theater, putting on various plays including ''[[Woyzeck]],'' and an improv night. The company put on a production of ''The American Pig'' at the [[Joseph Papp Public Theater]] for the [[New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater|New York Shakespeare Festival]] in New York City. In June 1970, after graduating from Yale, Winkler was asked to be part of the [[Yale Repertory Theatre]] company, which included [[James Naughton]] and [[Jill Eikenberry]]. During his time there, [[Cliff Robertson]], who had seen him perform in [[East Hampton (town), New York|East Hampton]], offered him a part in his film ''[[The Great Northfield Minnesota Raid]]''. Winkler had to decline because he had no understudy for his current role, and thus was unable to leave. He stayed with the Yale Repertory Theatre for a year and a half. In 1971, Winkler got a job at the [[Arena Stage]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] to work on the play, ''[[Moonchildren]],'' but was fired by director, [[Alan Schneider]]. In 1977, Winkler appeared in a TV special, "Henry Winkler Meets [[William Shakespeare]]," part of the ''[[CBS]] Festival of Lively Arts for Young People'' instructional series for children. With the assistance of [[Tom Aldredge]] as Shakespeare, Winkler, as himself, introduced an audience of children to ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'', ''[[The Taming of the Shrew]]'', ''[[Hamlet]],'' and ''[[Henry IV, Part 1|Henry IV]]'' and explained to them how Shakespeare's plays were produced at the [[Globe Theatre]] in [[London]] in the 17th century. He also played [[Romeo]] in the scene from ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'' in which [[Romeo]] slays [[Tybalt]] in a sword duel.{{cite web|url=http://bufvc.ac.uk/shakespeare/index.php/title/av38217 |title=British Universities Film & Video Council: "Henry Winkler Meets William Shakespeare" |publisher=Bufvc.ac.uk |date=1977-03-20 |accessdate=2014-12-09}}{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A04E0D8103BE334BC4053DFB466838C669EDE|last1=Klemesrud|first1=Judy|title=From Leather Jacket to Tights: The Fonz Makes It in Stratford|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 February 1977|page=26}} ==== Pantomime ==== Winkler appeared in his first [[pantomime]] at the [[New Wimbledon Theatre]], [[London]] in 2006, playing [[Captain Hook]] in ''[[Peter Pan]],'' replacing [[David Hasselhoff]] who pulled out when he was offered a TV role by [[Simon Cowell]]. He reprised the role in [[Woking]] for Christmas 2007. For the 2008/2009 season, he played [[Captain Hook]] at the [[Milton Keynes Theatre]] and donned the hook once again for the 2009/2010 panto season at the [[Liverpool Empire Theatre|Liverpool Empire]].{{cite news|last1=Lyall|first1=Sarah|title=Topsy-Turvy Christmas Foolery|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/22/theater/22panto.html|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=21 December 2009}} In December 2013, Winkler reprised his role of Captain Hook in ''Peter Pan'' at the Richmond Theatre in South West London. In the 2013 Broadway season, Winkler, [[Cheyenne Jackson]], [[Alicia Silverstone]], and [[Ari Graynor]] were announced to star in the David West Read play ''The Performers'' opening Nov 14, 2012, at The [[Longacre Theatre]].{{cite news|url=http://www.broadway.com/buzz/163136/cheyenne-jackson-and-henry-winkler-confirmed-to-star-in-broadway-porn-play-the-performers/|title=Cheyenne Jackson and Henry Winkler Confirmed to Star in Broadway Porn Play The Performers|work=Broadway.com| date=2012-07-26|accessdate= 2012-08-12}} === Author === In 1998, Winkler's agent at [[Creative Artists Agency|CAA]], Alan Berger, suggested Winkler write a children's book about dyslexia, but Winkler didn't think that he would be able to write because of his struggles with the learning disability. Berger was persistent, and a few years later, in 2003, he again suggested Winkler write. Winkler said yes. Berger suggested he co-write with author [[Lin Oliver]]. Winkler has since written 19 books. ==== Hank Zipzer books ==== Since 2003, Winkler has collaborated with [[Lin Oliver]] on a series of children's books about a 4th grade boy, [[Hank Zipzer]], who is [[dyslexic]]. Winkler also has the learning disability, which was not diagnosed until he was 31 and his stepson Jed, who was in the third grade, was tested;"Henry Winkler". ''[[Shatner's Raw Nerve]]'', 13 December 2009. the dyslexia was an unhappy{{cite web|url=http://www.greatschools.org/gk/articles/henry-winklers-dyslexic-hero/|title=Henry Winkler's Dyslexic Hero Gives Kids With Learning Difficulties the Last Laugh – Talking about LDs|publisher=GreatSchools|accessdate=27 April 2017}} part of his childhood. Winkler has published 17 books about his hero Zipzer, the "world's greatest underachiever."{{cite web |url=http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/grpress/index.ssf?/base/entertainment-2/120504699222730.xml&coll=6 |title=Grand Rapids Press |publisher=Mlive.com |date=2011-11-01 |accessdate=2012-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717091112/http://www.mlive.com/entertainment/grpress/index.ssf?%2Fbase%2Fentertainment-2%2F120504699222730.xml&coll=6 |archivedate=2012-07-17 |df= }} In July 2008, Winkler joined [[First News]] on their annual Reading Tour of schools where he read excerpts from his Hank Zipzer books. This has since become an annual tour.{{cite web|url=http://info.firstnews.co.uk|title=First News Children's Newspaper|publisher=[[Firstnews.co.uk]]|accessdate=2010-09-04}} In 2011, he donated books to Holy Rosary School, PA. The school was flooded out by [[Tropical Storm Lee (2011)|Tropical Storm Lee]]. On May 31, 2011, Winkler's book, ''I've Never Met an Idiot on the River,'' was published. It is a collection of his photographs and reflections drawn from his love of fly fishing and life with his family. === Other activities === * October 2008: Winkler appeared in a video on [[funnyordie.com]] with [[Ron Howard]], reprising their roles as Fonzie and [[Richie Cunningham]], encouraging people to vote for [[Barack Obama]]. The video titled "Ron Howard’s Call to Action" also featured [[Andy Griffith]].{{cite web|title=Ron Howard's Call For Obama With Andy Griffith And Henry Winkler|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2008/10/23/ron-howards-call-for-obam_n_137214.html|website=[[Huffington Post]]|accessdate=20 April 2015|date=23 October 2008}} * June 19, 2010: Winkler appeared on James Corden's ITV World Cup Live show. He represented the USA in the World Cup Wall Chart. * 2013: Winkler appeared in [[MGMT]]'s music video for "Your Life is a Lie," and made a special appearance with the band at FYF Fest 2013 where he played an oversized cowbell. == Honors and awards == * 1996: Class Day speaker at [[Yale University]], an honor accorded to distinguished Yale alumni * August 3, 2008: Guest conductor at the [[Boston Pops]] by the Sea Concert in [[Hyannis, Massachusetts]] * August 19, 2008: Unveiling of the [[Bronze Fonz]], a life-sized, bronze statue of Fonzie along the [[Milwaukee Riverwalk]].[http://www.wdtimes.com/articles/2008/08/16/news/news3.txt Artist ready for unveiling of 'Bronze Fonz']. ''Watertown Daily Times''. August 16, 2008. About the statue and artist Gerald Sawyer, of [[Milford, Wisconsin]] * March 29, 2010: Key to the [[City of Winnipeg]] for his contributions to education and literacy[http://news.globaltv.com/story.html?id=2737423 "The Fonz gets key to Winnipeg"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711101816/http://news.globaltv.com/story.html?id=2737423 |date=July 11, 2011}} ;[[Golden Globe Awards]] * 1977: Won – [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Best Actor – Television Series Musical or Comedy]] – ''[[Happy Days]]'' * 1978: Won – [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Television Series Musical or Comedy|Best Actor – Television Series Musical or Comedy]] – ''[[Happy Days]]'' (tied with [[Ron Howard]], also for ''[[Happy Days]]'') * 1978: Nominated – [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama|Best Actor – Motion Picture Drama]] – ''[[Heroes (1977 film)|Heroes]]'' * 1983: Nominated – [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Actor – Motion Picture Musical or Comedy]] – ''[[Night Shift (film)|Night Shift]]'' ;[[Daytime Emmy Award]] * 1995: Won – [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Children's Special|Outstanding Children's Special]] - [[12th Daytime Emmy Awards]] – ''[[CBS Schoolbreak Special]]'': "All the Kids Do It" * 2005: Won – [[Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Performer In An Animated Program|Outstanding Performer in an Animated Program]] - [[32nd Daytime Emmy Awards]] – ''[[Clifford's Puppy Days]]'' ;[[Primetime Emmy Awards]] * 1976: Nominated – [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]] – ''[[Happy Days]]'' * 1977: Nominated – [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]] – ''[[Happy Days]]'' * 1978: Nominated – [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Lead Actor in a Comedy Series]] – ''[[Happy Days]]'' * 1979: Nominated – Outstanding Informational Program – ''[[Who Are the DeBolts? And Where Did They Get Nineteen Kids?]]'' * 2000: Nominated – [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series|Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series]] – ''[[The Practice]]'' *2018: Pending – [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series]] – ''[[Barry (TV series)|Barry]]'' *'''Note''' – Also in 2000, Winkler had received an Emmy nomination for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series|Outstanding Guest Actor in a Comedy Series]] for an appearance on the short-lived series ''[[Battery Park (TV series)|Battery Park]]'', but the nomination was later withdrawn when it was pointed out later that the episode had aired after the Emmy's May 31 deadline.{{cite book|title=''[[TV Guide]]'' August 12–18, 2000. pg. 12}} ;[[Order of the British Empire]] In September 2011, Winkler was appointed an [[Honorary Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire|Honorary Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) ''for services to children with special educational needs and dyslexia in the UK''.{{cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.uk/inthenews/inthenews/a0074344/henry-winkler-receives-honorary-obe-for-services-to-children-with-special-educational-needs-and-dyslexia|title=Henry Winkler receives honorary OBE for services to children with special educational needs and dyslexia|work=UK Department of Education|date=February 11, 2011|accessdate=September 11, 2011}}{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/14923930|title=Henry Winkler, the Fonz in Happy Days, appointed OBE|accessdate=2011-09-15|work=BBC News|date=September 15, 2011}} ;[[National Literacy Trust]] Winkler was named by the [[National Literacy Trust]] as one of the United Kingdom’s top 10 Literacy Heroes on December 3, 2013.{{cite web | url=http://www.literacytrust.org.uk/news/5738_hrh_the_duchess_of_cornwall_hosts_reception_to_celebrate_the_uk_s_top_10_literacy_heroes | title=HRH The Duchess of Cornwall hosts reception to celebrate née Furstman){{cite web|last=Boughton |first=Victoria |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20134304,00.html |title=Happy Daze - Personal Success, Where Are They Now?, Henry Winkler |publisher=People.com |date=2001-05-07 |accessdate=2014-12-09}} since May 5, 1978; with her, he has two children, Zoe Emily (b. 1980), a pre-school teacher,{{cite news|last1=Preskill|first1=Adam|title=The Fonz's Daughter Chooses Her Own Path|url=http://la-confidential-magazine.com/living/articles/class-act|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[Los Angeles Confidential]]|date=October 2009}}{{cite news|last1=Segre|first1=Francesca|title=Vows: Zoe Winkler and Robert Reinis|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/19/fashion/weddings/19VOWS.html|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=18 July 2009}} and [[Max Winkler (director)|Max Daniel]] (b. August 18, 1983), a director. Winkler also has a stepson, Jed Weitzman, from Stacey's previous marriage with [[Howard Weitzman]]. Winkler is a cousin of actor [[Richard Belzer]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tvguide.com/PhotoGallery/Surprising-Celebrity-Family-1073313/1073326 |title=Henry Winkler Pictures, Richard Belzer Photos - Photo Gallery: Surprising Celebrity Family Ties |last= |first= |date= |website= |publisher=[[TV Guide]] |accessdate=October 31, 2014}} Winkler is the godfather of [[Bryce Dallas Howard]], daughter of ''[[Happy Days]]'' co-star [[Ron Howard]]. Henry was the 9th King of the Bacchus, Mardi Gras, Parade in New Orleans in 1977; the theme was "Happily Ever After". Winkler said he was named after his Uncle Helmut, who did not make it out of Germany during World War II. His middle name, Franklin, was in honor of President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]. He is an avid [[fly fisherman]], which he often does in [[Montana]]. On the rewards of this hobby, Winkler said: "The repetition of it, the sound of the water, I find it to be totally draining. Anything that bothers you is completely washed from your body. I see fly-fishing as a washing machine for your brain. My technique is still ugly as sin. But somehow I get the fish." He has also said "I have never eaten a trout in a restaurant let alone take it out of the river." == Works and publications == In addition to the Hank Zipzer series, which has 17 books, Winkler has written another series with Lin Oliver called ''Here's Hank,'' a prequel to the Zipzer stories.{{cite news|last1=Stebner|first1=Beth|title=How dyslexia made 'Happy Days' star Henry Winkler an author|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/dyslexia-made-henry-winkler-author-article-1.1617440|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|date=23 February 2014}} * Winkler, Henry. ''The Other Side of Henry Winkler: My Story.'' New York: Warner Books, 1976. {{ISBN|978-0-446-87340-6}} {{OCLC|3120426}} * Winkler, Henry. ''I've Never Met an Idiot on the River: Reflections on Family, Photography and Fly-Fishing.'' San Rafael, Calif: Insight Editions, 2011. {{ISBN|978-1-608-87020-2}} {{OCLC|670481642}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == === Interviews === * {{emmytvlegends name|henry-winkler}}, Emmys.
